channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gas Suspected in Fatal Blasts That Jolted a City in Taiwan
item.description: At least 22 people were killed and more than 270 injured when the southern city of Kaohsiung, Taiwan’s second-largest, was rocked by blasts that sent flames surging into the streets.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Suspected gas explosions on Thursday night killed at least 22 people in Kaohsiung, Taiwan.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Separating the Flies From the Tigers in Beijing Zoo Corruption Case
item.description: The corruption case against a former deputy director of the notoriously grim Beijing Zoo has raised the most unlikely questions.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Visitors feeding a giraffe at the Beijing Zoo. Accusations of corruption against a zoo official prompted some to ask if he could have profited at the animals' expense.

item.title: Tensions Escalate Between Israel and U.N.
item.description: Agency officials are enraged by strikes on its facilities and mounting civilian casualties in Gaza, while Israel accuses the U.N. of playing down Hamas’s role in the conflict.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: American Held in North Korea Says Health Is Failing
item.description: A pro-North Korea newspaper quoted Kenneth Bae, an imprisoned American missionary, as saying that he felt abandoned by the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: School Shelters Offer Limited Safety, and Even Less Comfort
item.description: Life for about 200,000 people packed into more than 80 schools serving as shelters in Gaza is full of deprivation and discomfort.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 200,000 displaced people in Gaza have packed into more than 80 schools run by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which cares for refugees.

item.title: 72-Hour Cease-Fire Announced in Gaza
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry announced that Israel and Hamas had agreed to a humanitarian cease-fire, which was to start on Friday, but that Israeli troops who have entered Gaza can remain.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: An explosion in Gaza City on Thursday.

item.title: Inquiry by C.I.A. Affirms Spying on Senate Panel
item.description: The inspector general’s account of how the C.I.A. secretly monitored a congressional committee charged with supervising its activities touched off angry criticism from members of the Senate.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and CARL HULSE
item.media:description: John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, apologized to two senators in connection with the penetration of a computer network.

item.title: Weak Links in China’s Food Chain
item.description: The OSI Group, one of the top meat producers in the United States with more than $6 billion in sales and about 20,000 employees in 17 countries, is enveloped in a food safety scandal in China.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE STROM
item.media:description: Workers processing food at Shanghai Husi Food, a unit of OSI Group.

item.title: Emergency Efforts in Africa to Contain Ebola as Toll Rises
item.description: New measures to combat the disease included house-to-house searches, advisories against travel and the deployment of the army and the police.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and DENISE GRADY
item.media:description: Medical staff working with Doctors Without Borders prepared to bring food to patients kept in an isolation area last week at an Ebola treatment center in Kailahun, Sierra Leone.

item.title: Ancient Haven for Refugees Sees Signs of Strain
item.description: Struggling to accommodate the thousands fleeing civil war in Syria, the Turkish government has quietly begun moving them to camps outside of the cities.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Five-year-old Duaa and her family are Syrian refugees from Aleppo living in Istanbul. Some Turks have demanded that Syrians be sent away from the city.

item.title: U.S. Seeks Release of Couple in Qatar, Creating Tensions With a Crucial Arab Ally
item.description: The State Department asked Qatar to lift a travel ban against an American couple being held in connection with the death of their adopted daughter.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: French Families Challenge Doctors on Wrenching End-of-Life Decisions
item.description: Doctors in France are being challenged on their right to make end-of-life decisions for patients who cannot communicate, though some doctors insist that making such calls is better for the family.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Pierre and Viviane Lambert in a French courtroom in January. They have appealed a ruling that their son could be allowed to die.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: On the Chinese Military’s New Map, What Borders?
item.description: A military newspaper said that the new map was “more accurate,” but China’s neighbors are interested in how the map demarcates borders in contested areas.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indian soldiers visiting the Buddhist monastery in Tawang, in the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh, which some official Chinese maps have shown as part of China.

item.title: Mexican Drug Lord Taunts the Authorities With Videos
item.description: In a line of work that usually operates out of the limelight, Servando Gómez has put himself — often with prominent people — in front of the camera.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pangolins Are ‘Being Eaten out of Existence,’ Conservation Group Says
item.description: Pushed to the edge of extinction in Asia by consumer demand, the scaly anteater faces increased poaching in Africa.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Pangolin scales en route from Africa to China that were seized in an antismuggling operation in Hong Kong's western waters in October 2013.

item.title: In India, Kerry to Meet New Prime Minister and Seek Improved Relations
item.description: With Prime Minister Narendra Modi pushing economic growth and better governance, the Obama administration has cast his election as a chance to bolster economic ties.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry at a dinner at the U.S. Ambassador's residence in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Prominent Activist Charged With Treason in Azerbaijan
item.description: The government charged the human rights activist Leyla Yunus and her husband with a variety of crimes and ordered Ms. Yunus to be detained for three months before her trial.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Imam in China Who Defended Party’s Policies in Xinjiang Is Stabbed to Death
item.description: Jume Tahir, the head of China’s largest mosque, was attacked after morning prayers in Kashgar in the troubled region of Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: London Has Plans for Rowdy Drunks
item.description: People who repeatedly commit alcohol-related crimes will be forced to wear ankle tags that monitor their drinking, the mayor of London said.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Break in Fighting Lets International Team Reach Site of Ukraine Crash
item.description: Ukrainian officials said they had suspended offensive operations against pro-Russia rebels to allow the monitors to reach the site safely.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Ilham Tohti Faces Criminal Trial Over Uighur Advocacy
item.description: Ilham Tohti, an economics professor and one of the few outspoken advocates for Uighurs, had been in detention since January.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Monitors Reach Flight 17 Crash Site in Ukraine After Days of Delays
item.description: The Ukrainian government said it had suspended operations against pro-Russia rebels in the area to allow the monitors safe passage, Reuters reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Quest for Demilitarization of Gaza Is Seen Getting Netanyahu Only So Far
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has begun talking about Gaza’s need for “social and economic relief” from decade-old Israeli restrictions on trade and travel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Alexander Litvinenko’s Death Examined as Ties Fray Between Russia and West
item.description: Judge Robert Owen said that it was “inevitable” that part of his final report about the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a fierce critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, would remain secret.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent who became a critic of the Russian government, in 2006 after he was poisoned with radioactive polonium.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Lessons From Poland’s Past
item.description: It has fallen to a legend of Solidarity to stand up to the political class and track the issue of secret C.I.A. prisons.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SLAWOMIR SIERAKOWSKI
